I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Pakistan accords high priority to proper monitoring of public sector 
development  projects  (PSDPs)  to  establish  and  upgrade  infrastructure  and  save  precious 
budgetary resources. It has requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) assistance in designing 
and implementing results-based monitoring (RBM) of project performance. The ongoing TA 
39821 is designing a dedicated project monitoring and evaluation system (PMES) software, 
which needs to be strengthened further, made sustainable, and its scope expanded to enable 
RBM  of  project  performance.  The  work  entails  capacity  development  at  the  federal  and 
provincial planning levels, expanding to include line ministries at the federal level and line 
departments at the provincial level, modifying existing software to include preparation of project 
documents to enable establishment of proper control points for RBM, and securing appropriate 
licenses to ensure sustainability of the PMES. The 2005 country strategy and program for 
Pakistan includes technical assistance (TA) for strengthening RBM, taking into account the 
findings of TA 3982. The Mission fielded in October 2005 reached an understanding with the 
Government  on  the  objectives,  scope,  approach,  terms  of  reference,  and  implementation 
arrangements of the TA2. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Pakistan has shown remarkable success in the turnaround of its economy promoted by 
far-reaching economic, fiscal, and governance reforms and supported by the international aid 
community. ADB has assisted the Government’s development and governance reform agenda 
and, as a result of its long-standing relationship, is now engaged in supporting Pakistan’s more 
challenging  second-generation  reforms.  These  include  addressing  the  Government’s 
institutional  constraints  to  development  and  thereby  improving  and  increasing  employment 
opportunities. In its medium-term development framework (MTDF) that covers the 2005-2010 
period, the Government recognizes the large backlog of infrastructure investments in both urban 
and  rural  Pakistan  that  are  required  to  improve  Pakistan’s  competitiveness,  augment 
employment opportunities, and reduce poverty. Infrastructure entails fixed assets and services 
related to transport (roads, airports, rail, mass transport systems, and ports), water supply and 
sanitation, solid waste treatment, education, health, and other small development projects like 
energy, power, telecom, irrigation, and water storage. 
 
3.  With economic growth exceeding an annual rate of 5%, Pakistan’s business climate and 
confidence have improved considerably since the year 2000. By June 2005 the fiscal deficit was 
reduced significantly to 3.3% of the gross domestic product, and its debt service ratio has 
dropped substantially. Reforms associated with reduced support to important sectors, including 
the social sectors (education, health, and safe access to basic services [water and electricity]) 
and local governance reforms pose challenges to local governments capability to implement its 
functions. 
 
4.  To further improve debt management, the Government is committed to maintaining 
prudent fiscal management, which limits its ability to borrow. Government estimates in MTDF 
indicate that only half of its investment needs can be covered from FY2006 to FY2010 under 
normal budget allocations. Modern approaches are required to effectively manage public sector 
resources and investments that are heavily constrained under the conventional planning and

approval processes. Particular effort is required to leverage the professional skills, incentives, 
and financial resources in establishing, managing, and monitoring PSDPs. Poor performance of 
PSDPs is often a result of ineffective monitoring and evaluation (M&E). Increasing M&E ability 
will result in minimum system losses, timely delivery, and the measurement of performance. 
While  the  Government  is  keen  to  monitor  PSDPs,  its  effective  RBM  capacity  requires 
improvement, as monitoring PSDP and helping public sector organizations to work better are 
one of the most persistent and difficult challenges.  
 
5.  The Government recognizes the need to improve PSDP performance and has initiated 
steps to identify weaknesses in the existing project management and monitoring system for 
necessary procedural streamlining and strengthening PSDP monitoring. Acknowledging that a 
consistent  RBM  policy  needs  to  be  developed  to  address  the  above  constraints,  the 
Government has established a high-level Prime Minister’s Monitoring Committee (PMC) to 
regularly monitor various project implementation issues and recommend measures for effective 
use of aid resources.  
 
6.  A coherent RBM strategy is needed, as no coherent policy and institutional framework 
exists, particularly at the provincial and local government levels. Policies need to address 
complexities across various levels of jurisdiction, blurring clear assignment of ownership and 
accountability,  and  division  of  regulatory  responsibilities,  consumer  protection,  and  service 
delivery functions and powers of public entities. While Local Government Ordinance (LGO) 
2001 assigns accountability to local governments, services are de facto maintained by agencies 
at a higher level. It is uncertain whether the local government will be able to fulfill the M&E 
function  as  prescribed  by  the  LGO,  as  the  project  management  strength  and  monitoring 
capacity of provincial, district and municipal governments are currently extremely limited and 
need to be strengthened via policies that improve project identification, structuring, management 
and monitoring capacity.  
 
7.  The Government’s ability to prepare, manage, and oversee RBM is largely absent. 
Because of the absence of proper RBM mechanisms, conflict of interest undermines PSDP 
usage and efficiency. Public sector expertise in project management and monitoring must also 
be nurtured, as M&E in Pakistan in the past often relied on external financing and management. 
Currently,  the  PMES  role  is  nonexistent,  even  for  larger  PSDP  monitoring,  as  there  is  a 
misunderstanding among some agencies on the benefit of the PMES and vested interests favor 
the status quo. It is thus essential that the PMES be well understood and the RBM modules 
developed through a consultative process. It is understood that the PMES can become really 
effective  if  it  raises  M&E  standards  and  is  found  more  viable  than  existing  public  sector 
monitoring mechanisms. Important constraints need to be addressed within the PMES, including 
capacity issues and the absence of in-house interdisciplinary skills in M&E. 
 
8.  Professional  support  is  required  to  develop  RBM  modules  and  need  to  be 
complemented with public sector commitment to enable RBM of PSDPs. The RBM TA and 
experience will shape policy and institutional development, including Government capabilities 
for monitoring and further managing the RBM process. The rationale for the RBM TA is to 
support the Government’s strategy for poverty reduction through sustainable economic growth 
and increased employment opportunities. The TA and the RBM approach are timely and fits well 
into  ADB’s  support  of  Pakistan’s  governance  reforms.  Therefore,  the  proposed  results-
orientation or RBM TA is a promising way forward and will reinforce ADB’s efforts for sustained 
improvement in project performance.

3
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The expected outcome of the TA is a streamlined system for Government M&E of 
PSDPs. The outcome will be realized by achieving the following outputs: (i) strengthened PMES 
at the Projects Wing (PW) of Federal Planning and Development Division (FPDD) and at the 
M&E units/cells of provincial planning and development boards/departments (PPDBs/PPDDs) in 
four  provinces:  Balochistan,  North  West  Frontier  Province,  Punjab,  and  Sindh;  (ii)  the 
assignment  of  responsibility  for  RBM  to  core  PW  staff;  (iii)  relevant  staff  of  key  line 
divisions/ministries trained in RBM; (iv) sustained information flow among stakeholders at the 
provincial  and  federal  governments  through  FPDD,  Economic  Affairs  Division  (EAD),  and 
PPDBs/PPDDs; and (v) establishment of a comprehensive database for key project activities 
and financial performance. The desired impact is to enhance the efficiency and quality of 
PSDPs. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  RBM  has  top  level  support  from  the  Government.  The  federal  Government  has 
established the PMC, initially monitoring all PSDPs over PRs 500 million, chaired by the advisor 
to the Prime Minister on finance. Members of the PMC include high-level representatives of 
government with the additional secretary of FPDD as the PMC secretary. The TA will provide 
necessary resources and expertise to support the Government's M&E effort by RBM of project 
implementation,  analyze  the  existing  weaknesses  and  reasons  for  delay  in  project 
implementation, and address the required remedial steps; and the decision-making authorities 
in  project  implementation.  The  PW  will  be assisted  by  a  TA  implementation  office  (TAIO) 
secretariat,  which  will  manage  the  PMES  and  monitor  overall  progress,  disseminate  RBM 
information  for  feedback  through  web  site,  bulletins,  and  seminars.  To  ensure  adequate 
implementation capacity, the TAIO will be properly staffed by February 2006. The TA will be 
implemented by a team of experienced international and domestic consultants. The consultants 
will  work  closely  with  the  Government's  counterpart  staff,  in  consultation  with  the  key 
stakeholders involved in the decision making, implementation, and monitoring of projects. The 
consultants’  work  will  be  closely  supervised  by  ADB,  and  guided  and  monitored  by  the 
Government through a high-level federal steering committee. Workshops will be organized to 
solicit views of the stakeholders at different levels of the Government on project implementation, 
portfolio management, and RBM issues and agree on remedial actions. The consultants will 
undertake  a  number  of  well-defined  and  sequenced  activities,  such  as  software  analysis 
including  institutional  setup;  training  needs  assessment,  training  manuals  on  PMES,  and 
imparting hands-on-training for relevant staff; development of RBM indicators; and preparation 
of an action plan and a road map for institutionalizing the PMES during the TA and on a 
sustained arrangement after its completion. 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented in three phases. In phase 1 (April to May 2006 [2 months]) a 
comprehensive diagnosis of the PMES will be carried out to identify key training requirements 
and issues and make recommendations along with a training plan to speed up the process. The 
diagnosis will include a review of existing Government monitoring procedures. The design 
phase (from June to September 2006) will start near the end of the diagnostic phase. To better 
understand issues and to recommend appropriate changes and improvements in the PMES and 
RBM, a pilot activity encompassing RBM of select projects will be carried out. The work will 
involve provision of support to PW for RBM and Electronic Government Directorate (EGD) to 
manage the portal and database of select projects. In phase 3 (from September 2006 to

December  2007  [16  months]),  the  scope  of  PMES-RBM  will  be  expanded  to  cover 
implementation of other key sector projects. During this phase, workshops will be conducted to 
share the results with and get feedback from key stakeholders. The TA will help develop the 
following tentative outputs and key results areas (KRAs). (The TA framework is in Appendix 1

(iii)  Output 3: RBM of key PSDPs via the PMES 
KRA 3.1 Review of RBM modules and incorporation of appropriate changes 
KRA 3.2 Expansion of RBM to cover other PSDPs in few key sectors 
 
12.  The  TA  will  help  develop  a  comprehensive  database  for  key  project  activities  and 
financial performance to strengthen the RBM system of FPDD and PPDDs/PPDB through an 
effective PMES with appropriate arrangements established for constant flow of information to 
those  concerned  in  the  decision-making  system,  including  EAD,  line  ministries  and 
departments. By doing this, the TA will integrate the PMES with the decision makers at higher 
levels and those directly involved in project implementation for efficient portfolio management 
and improved PSDP performance. The TA will identify the core staff requirement and logistic 
support for sustaining the PMES, define their responsibilities, and provide extensive training for 
capacity development within the PW, EAD, and the M&E units at PPDBs/PPDDs and the key 
line agencies.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
13.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $700,000. ADB will provide $500,000 equivalent 
financing  for  the  TA  from  the  ADB-funded  TA  program.  The  Government  will  finance  the 
remaining cost of $200,000 equivalent including provision of suitable counterpart staff, office 
accommodation, secretarial services, and telephone. Detailed cost estimates are in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  FPDD will be the Executing Agency and PW will be the Implementing Agency for the TA. 
A federal TA steering committee will be headed by the secretary of FPDD, with members from 
EAD, EGD, Finance Division, Planning Commission, lead line ministries, Auditor General's 
Office and PPDBs/PPDDs. The committee will meet regularly to provide periodic guidance on 
TA implementation, and will be responsible for implementing the different recommendations of 
the  TA.  An  executive  committee  headed  by  the  additional  secretary,  FPDD  will  also  be 
established  to  coordinate  the  efforts  and  FPDD  has  committed  to  provide  permanent 
counterpart  staff,  provide  suitable  offices,  and  facilitate  the  consultants’  interaction  with 
stakeholders, and in close collaboration with ADB, ensure the sustainability and expansion of 
the PMES to support RBM by the stakeholders.

5
15.  Given the nature of issues to be addressed, and capacity development through hands-
on-training to institutionalize RBM, the TA will be implemented over 2 years from the date the 
Government signs the TA letter and is expected to be completed by January 2008. FPPD will 
establish a TAIO under its PW for overall implementation, coordination and monitoring of the TA, 
to be headed by a federal project director. The PPDBs/PPDDs will appoint a project coordinator. 
In addition, EGD will coordinate TA implementation by interfacing with TAIO for complementing 
the software-related work, and will be provided with necessary logistical support in this regard. 
The TA will provide a total of 58 person-months of consulting services: including 54 domestic 
and 4 international. Outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. The 
consultants  will  be  individually  selected  during  TA  implementation  to  ensure  quick 
responsiveness to the emerging RBM needs articulated by the Government and FPDD. The 
consultants will be selected by ADB in consultation with the PW in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for selecting 
and engaging domestic consultants. The services of consultants are expected to commence in 
or  around  April  2006.  Equipment  to  be  provided  under  the  TA  will  be  procured  by  the 
consultants in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for Procurement. The review of the diagnostic 
phase is expected within 2 months of the fielding of consultants; of the design phase, within 4 
months of the fielding of consultants; and implementation as agreed upon with ADB. The 
consultants will provide reports as defined in their specific consulting contracts. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
16.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Pakistan for Results-Based Monitoring of Projects, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OUTPUT AND SEQUENCING 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will assist ADB and the Government in (i) formulating 
results-based monitoring (RBM) modules and completing the project monitoring and evaluation 
system (PMES) design for effective monitoring of public sector development projects (PSDPs); 
and  (ii)  strengthening  and  training  institutions  responsible  for  implementing  the  RBM.  The 
consultants will work with the secretary of the Prime Minister Monitoring Committee (PMC) and 
on a day-to-day basis with a dedicated team at Projects Wing (PW), the TA implementation 
office (TAIO). The TAIO will be responsible for managing PMES operationalization and RBM 
implementation. Consultants are expected to provide effective guidance for RBM and their 
advice will reflect international best practices and their applicability in Pakistan. 
A.  Output 1: Operationalize PMES 
  1.  KRA 1.1. Training Need Assessment for PMES Operationalization 
2.  Consultants will assess the training need for PMES operationalization, and propose well-
sequenced training solutions and a policy matrix taking into account relevant outputs provided 
under TA 3982.3 The consultants will help identify training issues and prepare the training plan, 
and assist in the national and regional training process. They will provide specific training plans 
and terms of reference for the working group associated with the PMES at PW. 
  2.  KRA 1.2. Implementation of Training to Speed Up the Process 
3.  Consultants will train the working groups in a consultative process. They will review the 
suitability of existing working groups and implement training as necessary to ensure timely 
PMES operation.4 Training will provide the broad parameters while implementation would allow 
for flexibility to adjust training arrangements to the individual requirement.  
3.  KRA 1.3. Support for Operationalization via Strengthening of PW, FPDD, 
EAD and EGD 
4.  The consultants in coordination with PW and EGD will ensure adequate management 
and  oversee  timely  implementation  of  the  PMES.  They  may  also  prepare  a  strategy, 
implementation and resource plan for capacity development that may include the use of existing 
higher education institutions. Any such training and capacity- development will complement, and 
not substitute for, the training and systems established under KRA 1.2. 
B.  Output 2: Develop Supporting RBM Modules in PMES 
1.  KRA 2.1. Development and Incorporation of Appropriate RBM Modules 
5.  To develop and incorporate the appropriate RBM modules in a timely manner, the 
consultant will, as part of the assignment, review the established monitoring processes of the 
Government; set out the structure, monitoring plan, and operating and procedures for RBM; and 
integrate RBM into the PMES. The software specialist and RBM and institutional specialist will 
be senior professionals experienced in preparing RBM and also have management oversight 
experience. Consultants will support development of a RBM strategy, plan, standard operating

2.  KRA 2.2. RBM of Select Projects 
6.  The pilot project includes RBM of select projects including selection and monitoring via 
the PMES. The pilot project will establish a RBM model and processes that are comparable with 
successful best practices, and will set RBM standards. Larger development projects with clearly 
identifiable outputs may be suitable candidates. It is important that RBM not be stand-alone 
monitoring; it will supplement the monitoring being done via the PMES to measure outputs. The 
consultants will have no responsibility for monitoring any individual project and will not intervene 
in decisions regarding the governance, management, or financial outcome of a project.  
C.  Output 3: RBM of Key PSDPs via PMES 
7.  In addition to the above measures, the line ministries require convincing that the PMES 
is a viable option and their RBM capacity need to be strengthened. It is critical that high-level 
government support continues to make sure that RBM of all PSDPs is done via the PMES as 
speedily as possible. 
1.  KRA  3.1.  Review  of  RBM  Modules  and  Incorporation  of  Appropriate 
Changes 
8.  The consultants through hands-on project teams will provide on-the-job assistance. The 
process will include selecting and monitoring pilot projects and transmitting feedback, making 
appropriate  module  changes  and  recommendations  for  monitoring  policies.  Consulting 
assistance will be required in incorporating the technical changes. 
2.  KRA 3.2. Expansion of RBM to Cover PSDPs in Key Sectors 
9.  Expansion of RBM to cover PSDPs in a few key sectors will start once a robust track 
record for the PMES is established. It will be critical that PW and other relevant ministries can 
tap the PMES for RBM of PSDP. Based on the market feedback, consulting assistance may be 
required for capacity development.  
D.  Consulting Expertise Required 
10.  Output 1. The consultants will be senior experts with 5–10 years relevant practical 
experience to strengthen and develop the capacity for PMES operationalization. This includes 
recruiting  a  suitable  team  of  management,  RBM,  institutional,  capacity  development,  and 
software experts. (about 25% of overall inputs). 
11.  Output 2.1. Developing and incorporating appropriate RBM modules requires mainly 
management, RBM, institutional and software experts (about 15% of overall inputs).  
12.  Output 2.2. The RBM of select projects requires extensive RBM skills and knowledge of 
international best practices (about 20% of overall inputs). 
13.  Output 3.1 RBM and institutional specialist and software specialist will be required for 
reviewing RBM modules and incorporating appropriate changes (about 10% of overall inputs). 
14.  Output 3.2. Capacity development is needed at federal, provincial and project levels for 
expanding coverage (about 10% overall inputs). 
15.  Experts in project management will provide about 20 % of overall inputs.

16.  Reporting. Each consultant will provide reports as determined in the specific contract.  
E.  Sequencing of the Assistance   
17.  First, it is expected that pilot PMES implementation will start by January 2006 within 
weeks of the start of the TA (December 2005). During this phase high emphasis is on outputs 
1.1 and 1.3. Some limited input on output 1.2 may be necessary. Concurrently, the TAIO will be 
established and adequately staffed. 
18.  Second, consultants selection will start in March 2006. 
19.  Third, full PMES operationalization and commencement of pilot RBM of select projects 
are scheduled for June 2006 with outputs 1.2 and 2.1 in a more advanced stage of preparation. 
20.  Fourth, the target date for review of RBM modules (output 3.1) is August 2006. 
21.  Fifth, expansion of RBM to cover other PSDPs (output 3.2) is scheduled for October 
2006. 
F.  Coordination with Ongoing Work and Other Initiatives 
22.  Since development of the PMES is ongoing, consultants will need to work closely with 
PW and ADB to take into account the updated status of the PMES. 
23.  The RBM TA will take into account and coordinate with initiatives of ADB such as the 
ongoing TA to streamline procedures to reduce delays in startup of development projects with 
the  Economic  Affairs  Division,  the  regional  TA  on  mainstreaming  for  support  of  poverty 
reduction in South Asia, Punjab, and Balochistan resource management programs and other 
similar  initiatives  of  the  World  Bank.  Coordination  will  be  ensured  through  PW,  Electronic 
Government Directorate and ADB as necessary.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Project Management and Monitoring Specialist (1 domestic, 18 person-months)  
 
1.   The  project  management  and  monitoring  specialist  (team  leader)  will  have  10  years 
experience in project planning, implementation, management, as well as monitoring and evaluation 
(M&E). As team leader he/she will also have worked with Asian Development Bank (ADB)-funded 
projects and technical assistances (TAs).  
 
2.   The team leader’s key responsibilities are as follows:  
(i)  Map Government monitoring processes and procedures. 
(ii)  Conduct a diagnostic study of Government operational policies and procedures from 
the perspective of identifying key factors for results-based monitoring (RBM) of 
projects. 
(iii)  Design a pilot activity for supporting the Electronic Governance Directorate (EGD) 
and Projects Wing (PW) in developing and implementing an effective RBM, follow 
up, and facilitation system for the different stages of projects. 
(iv)  Prepare  an  implementation  plan  for  training  needs  assessing  of  the  project 
monitoring and evaluation system (PMES). 
(v)  Support PW in carrying out the implementation plan and supervise and facilitate its 
implementation at the provincial level. 
(vi)  Support PW at the federal level in operationalizing and strengthening the PMES. 
(vii)  Assess  the  need  for  capacity  development  of  PW  and  facilitate  and  supervise 
similar  needs  assessment  for  the  M&E  cells  in  the  provincial  planning  and 
development boards/departments (PPDBs/PPDDs).  
(viii)  Design and implement capacity development activities. 
(ix)  Organize and coordinate meetings and dissemination and capacity development 
workshops with stakeholders. 
(x)  Coordinate project activities at the federal and provincial levels. 
(xi)  Supervise and coordinate the activities of consultants team. 
(xii)  Coordinate to the greatest extent possible with development partners. 
(xiii)  Prepare the inception report, quarterly progress reports, and final report. 
3.   The key deliverables are (i) an implementation plan for RBM of development projects; and 
(ii) an inception report, midterm progress report, and final TA report. 
 
B.  Institutional and Capacity Development Specialists (5 domestic, total of 30 person- 
months) 
 
4.   The short-term specialists will have at least 5 years experience in project management, 
institutional and capacity development, and procurement. They will report to the team leader. They

will put in 2 months of work each during phases 1, 2, and 3 of the TA (May–November 2006) as 
per work plan designed by the team leader in the first month of TA implementation.  
 
5.   The key responsibilities of the specialists are as follows  
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  in  mapping  the  Government  monitoring  processes  and 
procedures. 
(ii)  Assist in conducting a diagnostic study of the Government monitoring policies and 
procedures to identify key factors for RBM of projects. 
(iii)  Execute a pilot activity for supporting the EGD and PW in implementing an effective 
RBM, follow-up, and facilitation system for the different stages of projects. 
(iv)  Assist in preparing an implementation plan for training need assessment of PMES. 
(v)  Support PW in carrying out the implementation plan and supervise and facilitate its 
implementation at the provincial level. 
(vi)  Support PW at the federal level in operationalizing and strengthening of PMES. 
(vii)  Assist in assessing capacity development needs for respective P&DDs. 
(viii)  Implement capacity development activities in the respective P&DDs. 
(ix)  Assist in organizing, coordinating, and documenting meetings and dissemination 
and capacity development workshops with stakeholders. 
(x)  Coordinate to the greatest extent possible with development partners. 
(xi)  Coordinate overall TA activities at the respective PPDBs/Ds, executing agencies 
(EAs) and project management units (PMUs).   
(xii)  Assist the team leader in preparing the inception report, quarterly progress reports, 
and final report.  
 
C.  Software Specialist (1 domestic, 6 person-months)  
 
6.   The specialist will have at least 5 years experience in management information system 
(MIS)/software development, and specific experience in developing and operationalizing project 
monitoring and tracking systems. The specialist will report to the team leader, and will be expected 
to provide input during April–September 2006. 
 
7.   The key responsibilities are as follows:  
(i)  Develop an understanding of the Government systems and procedures involved in 
the RBM of development projects.  
(ii)  Study the existing PMES established under the ADB-funded TA for strengthening 
portfolio performance and monitoring. 
(iii)  Extending the PMES established under the above TA to include RBM of activities. 
Make modifications in the PMES, and/or develop additional modules as necessary 
to include RBM of activities. 
(iv)  Operationalize the PMES in PW and PPDBs/Ds.

D.   RBM and Institutional Specialist (1 international, 4 person-months)  
 
8.   The specialist will have at least 10 years experience in project management, institutional 
development and capacity development, and procurement; and will have previous work experience 
with other externally aided projects. The international consultant will report to the team leader and 
will be expected to provide 2 person-months of input during phase 1 of the TA (May–June 2006), 
and the remaining in phase 2 (July 2006–August 2006) as per the agreed–upon work plan.  
 
9.   The key responsibilities are as follows:  
(i)  Share with executing and implementing agencies lessons learned and best practice 
from international experience in RBM of projects. 
(ii)  Assess the relevance of such experience with the situation in Pakistan. Suggest 
measures to implement RBM of development projects in the country. 
(iii)  Propose actions to improve harmonization of Government monitoring procedures, 
based on experience in other countries. 
(iv)  Propose measures to simplify and improve monitoring documents and handbooks to 
make them more user-friendly for executing and implementing agencies. 
(v)  Provide written inputs for the diagnostic study and implementation plan. Assist the 
team leader, as needed, in undertaking the implementation plan. 
(vi)  Undertake other assignments as requested by the team leader.
